Authors:
Garth Holman, Peter Del Tredici, Nathan P. Havill, Nam Sook
Lee, Richard Cronn, Sarah Mathews, Linda Raubeson, Christopher S.
Campbell
Title:
Phylogenomic evidence detects a new species of hemlock
(Tsuga, Pinaceae) and possible ancient hybridization in the genus.
Keywords:
chloroplast capture, island endemic, plastid genomes,
quantitative morphology, species concepts, Ulleungdo
Abstract:
Species delimitation in Pinaceae is often challenged by
limited morphological differentiation and hybridization. In Tsuga
(hemlocks), the species problem has been most challenging among eastern
Asian taxa, wherein the number of species has ranged from three to five
in previous studies. We assessed species relationships among eastern
Asian Tsuga with DNA sequence data from nearly complete chloroplast
genomes, two low-copy nuclear 4-coumarase-ligase (4CL) genes, morphology
of cones and leaves, plus phenology. Nine of the 68 protein-coding
chloroplast genes in Tsuga are reduced in length compared with other
Pinaceae. Moderate cpDNA support resolves T. caroliniana as sister to a
clade of T. diversifolia and hemlocks from Ulleung Island (Ulleungdo),
Korea. In our 4CL trees Japanese endemic T. diversifolia and T.
sieboldii, plus Ulleungdo hemlocks form a well-supported clade here
referred to as the oceanic hemlocks. Morphology also supports this group
as distinct from other eastern Asian hemlocks. Tsuga sieboldii, in
contrast, is strongly supported as sister to the widespread eastern
Asian T. chinensis by cpDNA, whereas 4CL strongly supports a
sister-group relationship of T. chinensis and eastern North American T.
caroliniana. These divergent topologies suggest that T. sieboldii
captured the chloroplast of T. chinensis (or a close relative) through
ancient hybridization and subsequent introgression. The Ulleungdo
hemlock forms a phenotypic cluster that is distinct from other eastern
Asian species in leaf and cone morphology and phenology, and we
therefore propose it as a new species, Tsuga ulleungensis, the first
endemic gymnosperm to be described from the island.
